title: Magnetic fields - cutting two bar magnets in half

content.question: Two bar magnets, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, separated from each other, are cut in half along the dashed lines shown in the diagram. Each half of each magnet is kept in its original orientation. Which of the following correctly describes whether the two halves of Magnet <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> attract each other and whether the two halves of Magnet <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> attract each other and provides a correct justification?

choices.label: The two halves of each magnet will attract, because cutting a magnet does not change the orientation of the magnetic domains within the magnets.
The two halves of each magnet will attract, because both magnets will still have a magnetic dipole.
The two halves of each magnet will not attract, because Magnet <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> will no longer be a magnetic dipole.

The two halves of each magnet will not attract, because the halves of Magnet <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> will have dipoles oriented in the same direction.

content.answer: The two halves of each magnet will not attract, because the halves of Magnet <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math> will have dipoles oriented in the same direction.
